syllabus:
**Art Historiography 2020 (Tentative Program)**

**The course introduces the student to the history, methods and trends of the discipline of art history. It develops an understanding of the important theoretical developments that took place in the discipline from the Renaissance to the present. Prominent art historians and their theories are commented through the reading of exemplary texts. Their reception and influence  are analysed and contextualized. Changing methods of interpretation are carefully examined and compared through the scope of a selection of texts that cover different hermeneutic approaches and perspectives.**

**Instructions for the oral presentations and term papers delivered in the Art Historiography Course**

**Oral Presentation (duration 30-40 minutes)**

Please provide a handout with your name and student number with the following information 

•       Title, date, publisher etc. of the book you are presenting (when it is a translation, please indicate the first edition in the original language) 

•       The chapter(s) of the book you are analyzing

•       The articulation of your presentation (it may be related to the structure of the chapter(s)) 

•       The reception of the book (reviews, references in later publications)

•       Bibliography 

**Term papers**

**General remarks:**

            In your paper, try to be as clear as possible, without being too pedantic. You must be coherent in your argumentation in any part of your text, from the beginning to the end. Each paragraph must also follow a coherent structure. Each argument or idea should obey to a logical continuity. Don’t jump from one idea to another without justifying it. You must accompany the reader in your train of thought. Never forget the main purpose or reason, which led you to provide the reader with a specific kind of information. In two words: be consistent!

**Introduction**

Try to catch the attention of the reader through an anecdote (some historical facts related to the publication date of the book you are reviewing or any element related to the context and the main argumentation of your paper). This catchy element should tease the reader and give him/her the envy to read your paper (ask yourself whether you would like to read your own paper). You can briefly synthesize the outlines of your paper and introduce the main issues you will discuss in each chapter, but don’t spoil the whole stuff. Let also the reader discover new things throughout the entire paper. Please avoid tautologies such as for example mentioning in your introduction that you will have a conclusion to your paper.

**Content and Structure**

•       Present the main stakes of the book you are reviewing. Describe its structure and its content (summarize briefly the different chapters that constitute the book); try to describe in which way the argumentation is structured and focus your attention on the chapter you have been assigned to analyze critically. Please try to show to which extent the part you are analyzing is coherent, according to the following issues:

•       The central thesis can be found in that specific chapter, and/or the most problematic issues can be found within this chapter

•       The author is the most pertinent or the less pertinent within this chapter; 

•       The critics and reviews of the book focus on the thesis developed in this chapter etc.

•       The analysis of the selected chapter(s) should detail the form and the content of the thesis it embraces. Comment key passages and paraphrase them.

**Method**

Your review must be based on a critical reading of the part you have been assigned to comment. This must be done through the reviews you collected on the book, the discussion we had in the classroom, and your own good sense. Your comment will have more strength if you provide the socio-historical as well as intellectual context in which the author and the book are inscribed. Some authors do explicitly refer to other scholars / texts / to legitimize their own point of view. They may explicitly frame their research within a specific intellectual, scientific, methodological context. In any case, you must take into account the career of the authors, their methods, the influences they received from their "masters", the colleagues that support(ed) or contradict(ed) their vision, the writings to which the text may respond and echo.

**Quotations and footnotes**

            In general, your paper relies essentially on your readings. You must in this respect report all your references (books, articles, DVDs, websites, etc.) in the footnotes, no matter you are quoting or paraphrasing. (For the technical details, see below). You also have to make clear who is speaking, and where each idea comes from. 

            The footnotes serve also to provide the reader with further information you cannot put in the main text. This can be helpful, when you want to keep some continuity to the argumentation of the main text.

 Length: 10-15 pages, Times New Roman, line space 1.5 (bibliography, appendix etc. not included)
